clinical_study.brief_title: Multisite Study: Parental Training Using Video Modelling to Develop Social Skills in Children With Autism
clinical_study.official_title: Multisite Study: Acquisition of Social Skills in Children With Autism Using Video Modeling in Parental Training

collaborator.agency: Mackenzie Presbiterian University, São Paulo, Brazil

brief_summary.textblock:
This is a Brazilian multisite study to test the efficacy of an Applied Behavior Analysis (ABA) parent training using video modeling to teach parents of children with Autism techniques to apply to their children in order to improve eye contact and joint attention behaviors.
Our hypothesis is that children with Autism whose parents will be trained by videomodeling will have better eye contact and joint attention behaviors compared to children with Autism whose parents will not be trained.

detailed_description.textblock:
Applied Behavior Analysis (ABA) is an intervention with proven efficacy in treating impairments on social functioning and daily-life activities of individuals with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD). In Brazil we have a limited number of qualified professionals and an increasing demand of families non-served in the public health system.
Our main objective is to standardize and test the efficacy of a model for parent training using video modeling for teaching eye contact and joint attention behaviors in children with ASD. These two behaviors are essential to develop adequate social interaction, the core impaired domain in ASD. It is a multisite study to be carried out at the Universidade Federal de São Paulo, Universidade de São Paulo and Universidade Presbiteriana Mackenzie. The sample will be composed of 70 children divided in control and intervention groups that will be randomly chosen. The intervention should be carried out in 21 weeks.

primary_outcome.description: acquisition of new behaviors (eye contact and joint attention) checked through taped interactions between child and a family member

primary_outcome.measure: Acquisition from baseline of new behaviors at 16 weeks
primary_outcome.description: acquisition of new behaviors (eye contact and joint attention) checked through taped interactions between child and a family member

primary_outcome.measure: Acquisition from baseline of new behaviors at 21 weeks
primary_outcome.description: acquisition of new behaviors (eye contact and joint attention) checked through taped interactions between child and a family member

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline in Eye-tracking at 21 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: Latency, duration, and sequence of visual fixations measured with eye-tracking

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline in Vineland Scale at 21 weeks
Change from baseline in SON-R 2½-7 at 21 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: Improve on SON-R 2½-7 that is an intelligence coefficient test developed for deaf people

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline in Zaritt Burden Interview at 21 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: The Zaritt Burden Interview measures the caregiver burden of taking care of the relative with psychiatric disorder

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline in OERA at 21 weeks
secondary_outcome.description: OERA (Observação Estruturada para Rastreamento de Autismo) is a taped structured observation to screen Autism that was developed by Brazilian researchers.

other_outcome.measure: Change from baseline in KAP at 21 weeks
other_outcome.description: Improvement on the knowledge, attitude and practice (KAP) questionnaire

other_outcome.measure: Change from baseline in Hamilton scalels and at 21 weeks
other_outcome.description: Improvement on the Hamilton Depression and Anxiety scales of the caregiver

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Clinical Diagnosis of Autism Spectrum Disorders
- Diagnosis of Autism Spectrum Disorders by means of ADI
- IQ equal or lower than 70 by means of SON
- Main caregiver's level of education > primary education
Exclusion Criteria:
- IQ lower than 50 by means of SON
- Child who is receiving ABA therapy at least 10 hours per week
- Main caregiver diagnosed with Autism Spectrum Disorders
